title: Sales Under £2 Million Lead Transaction Surge in Prime Central London
text:
Home buyers in prime central London made a return to the market in the third quarter, as the city’s most high-end areas saw transactions swell, according to a report from LonRes released Thursday in the U.K.



Overall, sales were up 14% compared to the same time last year, the real estate data firm said.



More: For Plant Lovers, an Ideal Abode in London

“Despite political uncertainty and an absence of any discernible resolution to the Brexit saga, the prime central London market was busier this summer than last,” said Marcus Dixon, head of research at LonRes, in the report.



Driving the increases was the lower end of the market, which coincidentally has also witnessed the larger price falls, suggesting that the buyers who have returned to the market are looking for value.



Homes priced at under £2 million (US$2.56 million) saw transaction levels surge 26% annually in the third quarter, while values dropped 4% in the same time.



Properties priced between £2 million and £5 million saw a 12% increase in sales while price growth was almost non-existent at just 0.1%.



From Penta: Hockney’s ‘Sur la Terrasse’ Could Net $45 Million at Christie’s

But the top end of the market saw transactions plummet 29% in the third quarter, while values rose 3.3%, according to the report.



“Talk of a potential change to top-end stamp duty could lie behind the fall,” Mr. Dixon said, “as buyers likely to make the greatest savings on a stamp duty change, sit it out and play a game of wait and see.”

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has been considering reversing the rates of stamp duty on homes sold for more than £1.5 million, which almost doubled in 2014, Mansion Global previously reported.



Overall, prime central London saw its prices fall 5.8%, leaving them 17% lower than at their 2014 peak and 13% less than the values seen in the three months prior to the EU referendum, Mr. Dixon said.
